title: Food Safety and Processing Technology
requirements:
Not for Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences Majors and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: In modern cities, a wide assortment of food products is available in the markets and consumers are able to enjoy these delicious foods conveniently and safely. Behind the scenes of food enjoyment, lots of science and technology has been applied in their manufacturing processes to ensure that the food products are preserved in high standards of quality, nutrition and safety. Among those food manufacturing and processing methods, however, some of them are quite controversial and thus arouse many public concerns over food safety and security issues. This course is designed for the general students to provide them with some key concepts and scientific knowledge in food preservation, processing technology and food safety control, as well as to explore the interactive relationships between them. Through learning the basic properties of foodborne hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems, students are able to enhance the understandings on the principles and practices of respective food preservation methods and processing technologies. Meanwhile, the potential risks and adverse effects of particular food processing technologies will be discussed. Furthermore, some highly concerning topics and incidents about food safety will be analysed based on scientific facts and discussed from different perspectives. After finishing the course, students are encouraged to use the acquired knowledge to make better food choices, distinguish the fallacies about food and appraise the impact of modern technology on human food safety and security.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be able to:  identify the foodborne hazards in various aspects and describe their properties  elucidate the causes and mechanisms of foodborne diseases  identify the applications of food preservation methods and technologies in daily food products and explain their working principles  apply the knowledge to make better food choices and safer domestic food preparations  analyse the contemporary food issues with scientific discipline and make informed judgment in some controversies of food concerns  appraise the pros and cons of food processing technologies and evaluate their impact on food safety and security
syllabus: This course mainly focuses on the food safety and the related processing technology. The course begins with introducing the common foodborne hazards that people come across in daily lives. Then, the principles of various contemporary food preservation methods and processing technologies protecting foods from spoilage or contamination are explicated. Finally, selected topics of food issues and safety concerns are studied. The relationship between food processing and safety are analysed through those specific discussions.   Part 1.         Foodborne Hazards             The initial part of the course provides students with a basic understanding on the biological and chemical food hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems. The fundamental knowledge about food microorganism will be elucidated, which include the general property of microbes, the common characteristic of foodborne pathogen and the mechanism of how they cause the foodborne illnesses. On the other side, the food chemicals including toxin, allergen and contaminant that leading adverse effects to human will be introduced and some mechanisms of common food poisoning and allergy will be explained.   Biological Hazards in Food  Understanding of food microorganisms  Essential conditions for food microbe growth  Characteristics and sources of foodborne pathogens  Causes and effects of foodborne illnesses: infection and intoxication   Chemical Hazards in Food  Nature of food toxins  Existence and origins of food contaminants  Understanding of food allergens  Causes and effects of food poisoning and hypersensitive   Part 2.         Food Preservation Method and Processing Technology            This part covers the theories and practices of food preservation and safety control. The basic principles and mechanisms of modern-day food processing technologies for the preservation purpose will be explained. Moreover, the concept and principle of Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP), which is a prevalent food safety control system executing in modern food premises, will be briefly introduced in this section.   Food Processing  Principles and objectives of food processing  Effects of processing treatments on food properties       Food Preservation Method and Technology  High temperature processing: pasteurization and sterilization  Low temperature processing: chilling and freezing  Control of atmospheres in package   Control of water activity  Control of pH  Food irradiation  Functions and regulations of food additives  Hurdle Technology   Food Safety System: HACCP  Basic concept of HACCP: from farm to fork  Seven principles to develop HACCP plan for a food production  Methodology of risk assessment   Part 3. Food Issues and Concerns            Selected food issues and safety concerns will be presented in the last part of the course. The background of individual food safety topics will be introduced and the credibility of the concerns will be analysed based on the scientific knowledge and facts. The correlation between food manufacturing and safety issues will be studied. The limitations of the current food safety control system are also revealed. And the social impacts of those food safety issues will be discussed in the lesson as well.   Food Safety Topics  Foodborne outbreaks  Food frauds  Genetically modified foods  Uses of hormones and food additives

title: Biotechnology in biodiversity, conservation, environment and sustainability
requirements: Not for majors in School of Life Sciences & students in the con areas of Natural Sciences Prog: Biological Sciences; Biotechnology; Environmental Studies; or Food & Nutrition. Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH" or "UGFN” as prefix.
description: In recent years, the United Nations had proposed a global plan aiming to end poverty and protect the globe, and ensure that people living on this planet enjoy peace and prosperity by 2030. The goal is going to be achieved and performed by 17 integrated subdivisions, which are also known as the sustainable development goals (SDGs). Biodiversity, conservation, environmental management, and related technologies are essential and are brought together under this bigger theme of sustainability. Biotechnology, here thus plays a great role, as it infiltrates in different part of our lives — from the food we eat to how we collect them, the drugs we take to treat illnesses, the fuel we use to power up devices and even the conservation of biodiversity and the environmental health. While biotechnology is a broad discipline that exploits different biological processes, organisms, cells or cellular components to develop new and effective technologies and is a newly emerged and an ongoing field in biological sciences, it offers opportunities to aid achieving different global matters that are happening currently or in the foreseeable future, especially issues relating but not limited to food crisis, one health, energy shortage, sustainable infrastructure and biodiversity in different habitats, etc.This course provides a wide scope of knowledge relating to biotechnology that aims to stimulate thoughts and broaden the horizon of students from different background. It also allows the students to embrace the beauty and understand the constraint, including ethical, social, environmental and technological challenges of biotechnology. This course focuses on three major themes: 1). Introduction of the basic biotechnology knowledge of genetics and extended biotechnology techniques, 2). Showcases of the latest biotechnological developments and applications in various aspects of life sciences, 3). Discussion of key values of biotechnology and the philosophical, moral and ethical issues of biotechnology. Ultimately, this course aims at raising the awareness and promote the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to SDG#2 Zero Hunger, SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being, SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities, SDG#14 Life Below Water and SDG#15 Life On Land, to the students.

description: The course aims at providing an introduction to the formation of the cosmos and the origin of life from an astrophysical perspective. description: Hong Kong is very famous for its superb cuisine, which is a fantastic fusion of eastern and western styles. Cooking is both an art and a science. Good tasting foods and drinks are the results of perfect matches of ingredients and cooking methods. Foods and drinks is related to chemistry closely. Having some understanding about the chemistry of the food ingredients and the various cooking methods can help appreciating the connections between science and human life. This course will discuss the Hong Kong cuisine culture from the chemistry perspective, to explain why these famous foods and drinks are so tasty and popular. title: Perspectives in Risk Management and Modern Society
requirements:
Not for RMSC,STAT,QFRM,CDAS Majors, students in Data Science or Mathematical Sciences concentration areas of Natural Sciences Programme, and students who have taken RMSC2001
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: Risk management is without doubt one of the most important issues in various aspects of the modern society. Quantifying risk management is not only a management tool, but is also a scientific activity. This course aims at introducing the role of risk management in modern society. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the role of risk management and its impact on every day life both at personal and institutional level.
outcome: This course develops the students' basic concepts of risk management in broad terms. After the course, the students are expected:              to understand the evolution of risk management science in the modem society (T1, T2, T6).              to identify and evaluate potential risks in daily life (T1, T3).              to develop a systematic, although conceptual, approach in handling various types of risks in life and work (T3, T4, T5).              to appreciate the need of continuous development in risk management techniques to adapt the ever-changing economical and social environment (T1, T6).   Topics: T1: Basic risk management concepts: classification, identification, evaluation. T2: Economic theories underlying risk management. T3: Risk management in daily life: e.g. health risk and retirement risk. T4: Risk management using insurance. T5: Risk management using financial derivatives. T6: A case study of risk management evolution in modern society.
syllabus: This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risks and risk measures from ascientific perspective. The course will discuss on various roles that risk plays in our modern society. Topics include: 1. The evolution and development of modern risk management practice. The shift in philosophy from solely insurance buying for pure risks to integrated risk management for much broader scope of risks. Related concepts, such as perils, hazards and adverse selection, will also be discussed through various real life examples;2. Classification and identification of risks. We shall use daily life examples to arouse students’ sensitivity to risks.3. Risk management techniques such as risk avoidance, risk control and risk financing.4. Basic principles underlying insurance. We shall introduce the development of this traditional risk management tool for new and complicated types of risks, such as terrorism and natural disasters.5. Banking industry experienced significant and continuous changes in their ways of handling risks. We shall discuss the history of this evolution as an example of the development of risk management concept.6. Case studies (e.g. SARS, Hurricane Katrina, 911 attacks) will be discussed in order to illustrate the risks in different aspects of our life and the appropriate tools to manage it.

title: Human Evolution
requirements:
UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2810. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810.)  What does it mean to be human? Where did we come from? Where are we going? This course investigates long-term evolutionary perspectives on the human species. The basics of evolution and natural selection as scientific theories are clearly set out and examined, and common misconceptions discussed. Evidence for the evolution of mammals and primates is reviewed and discussed, and the common characteristics of these species are highlighted, demonstrating the connections between humans and other forms of life. The course covers what we know about human ancestors and the evolution of modern humans. Students are introduced to the wide range of human adaptations to local conditions across contemporary cultures and the variety of relationships that human populations have with the environment. Students are encouraged to use the knowledge they have acquired to ask: are these relationships always sustainable? Looking to the future: what are our responsibilities both to future generations of humans and towards other species with which we share our world? This course aims to give students an understanding and appreciation of evolutionary perspectives on the place of humans in the world, the variety of contemporary human societies, and a broad perspective on the complexity of the relationship between humans, the environment and other species.
outcome: In this course students learn about the nature of scientific theories and their development, as well as the use of evidence in evaluating hypotheses. Students are also exposed to the potential for misunderstandings of scientific theory and the distinction between fact and value. Comparative abilities are emphasised through reviewing common features of the life-course of a variety of animals and the influence of animal habitats, with particular focus on closely related primate species.   The history of human evolution is introduced to students, focussing on the emergence of universal capacities such as language, technology, art and culture. Students are encouraged to learn about and appreciate the variety of human cultures and the flexibility of humans in adapting to local environments. A comparative perspective on human culture is encouraged through a focus on the common subsistence needs of all humans, and the variety of practices by which these needs are met.   Students are exposed to a wide perspective on the place of the human species in the world. They are encouraged to exercise long-term evaluations of, and exercise a sense of judgement about the impact and sustainability of human action, both in relation to the environment and other species as well as future generations of the human species. Students are thus encouraged to think about their own place in society.

description: (UGEB2505 is double-coded with ANTH2740.) How we understand the past defines the way how we understand our current situation. Archaeology is a dynamic discipline that has tremendously expanded our knowledge about the past, but this subject is not just about digging and doing fieldwork. A wide range of new techniques (e.g., metallurgy, zoology, and 3d stimulation) and research methods have been incorporated into current archaeological research, and eventually transformed the understanding of ourselves and our culture in many ways. This course provides a general introduction in terms of two specific domains: 1) basic archaeological science that changed the research paradigm of human culture and history; 2) an overall history about ancient technology illustrated by new research techniques to explain how this modern world took shape. Moreover, this course provides hands-on practice to cultivate students’ cross-disciplinary research skills and prepare them for the arrival of a new, digitalized research era.
outcome: #1    Understand what is “scientific reasoning”, and be able to evaluate claims about the past by combining anthropological knowledge and understanding of scientific techniques; #2   General understanding about the history of technology and basic knowledge background to appreciate technological achievements in the past; #3   Equip students with skills to conduct digital humanities research and foundation to develop cross-disciplinary study; #4     Inspire students of different backgrounds to employ new techniques addressing problems challenging most cultural heritage projects that our current society is encountering.

description: The course aims at studying the human exploration of astronomical phenomena in the history, thereby disclosing the interplay between astronomical activities and the cultural, social, and scientific aspects of human lives, as well as the deep and authentic relation between the celestial bodies and the lives on earth. Topics include: astronomical traditions of ancient civilizations and their social functions, astronomical phenomena found in ancient books, literature, myths and their scientific explanations; the impact of scientific revolutions in the Renaissance and the 20th century on our views of the universe, human thought and modern civilization, the influence of cosmic events on the lives on earth, the quest for extraterrestrial lives. Star-gazing activity is included to enhance students’ interest. The course is designed to help students with little or no science background gain intellectual perspectives on the interplay between science and culture, and our subtle relation with the universe.

title: Games and Strategic Thinking

description: The aim of this course is to study games and strategies from the mathematical perspective. We investigate the manner in which rational people interact when there are competitions. This applies to parlour games and more importantly to economy, social psychology, politics and business. We will introduce the great discoveries of Von Neumann and Nash, and discuss their impact on society. Also, we will use examples of various types of games to illustrate how some basic mathematical methods can lead to optimal strategies for decision making.
outcome: We expect students to learn how to formulate real life problems that involve strategic interaction as mathematical games, and to be able to use the appropriate mathematical tools to study such games. We expect students to be able to: Understand the concepts of a game, such as players, positions, moves, strategies, information, rationality, game trees, outcomes, payoffs, zero-sum and non-zero-sum games, Pareto optimality, equilibrium, sequential games, cooperative games. Formulate and solve simple matrix games, and to use them for investigating practical situations. Appreciate how game theory may be applied in other fields of knowledge, such as economics, political science, biology, and how it may be applied in decision making processes, such as auction pricing, cost allocations problems, military planning, diplomacy. Be aware of the aims, scope and limitations of game theory.

Two-person zero-sum games, two-person non-zero sum games, and their applications.Selected topics: Sequential games; complete and incomplete information games and their applications. Cooperative and non-cooperative games, N-person games and their applications. Combinatorial games.Relevant mathematical tools, such as matrices, probability and graphs, will be developed in the course.

description: This course offers a friendly introduction to materials science, highlighting technologies from constructing a lightweight supersonic aircraft to fabricating a computer microprocessor, and its connection to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Designed for students with little science background, it covers essential topics like metals, polymers, ceramics, composites, and semiconductors. Key topics include their basic properties, structures, processing techniques, applications, and those of the modern advanced materials, all in connection with pressing global issues. SDGs include (1) materials and technology for achieving affordable and clean energy such as solar cells and fuel cells (SDG-7), (2) the materials in sustainable technology industry, such as bioplastic and hydrogen energy (SDG-9), (3) on the potential of employing biodegradable materials, improving material supply chains of plastic and electronic devices, and developing end-users strategies for sustainable consumptions and productions (SDG-12), (4) global collaborations to address issues related to the uneven distribution of material resources, processing technologies, and capital (SDG-10 and -17), (5) the impact of plastic and electronic devices on lives and environment (SDG-14 and -15). A system perspective with relevant cases will be employed to explore the roles of materials science in sustainability issues, its economic, social and environmental implications, and relevance to different social groups (e.g. local and global communities, companies, government, NGOs). Students will also have a chance to reflect on their own roles.
outcome: Students are expected to:  acquire some knowledge to classify different types of materials.  explain and compare various approaches in materials investigations.  be able to understand why some materials can be used and some cannot.  develop a perspective of relating materials to human development and society, and establish its relationship with SDGs such as sustainable energy, reduced equalities, partnerships for goals, consumption and production, and life on land (and below water).  recognize and evaluate environmental issues while using or disposing of materials and how these are related to the SDGs.  list what sorts of materials are being used in some hi-tech applications, including the technology used in sustainable energy system  relate and synthesis the insights learnt from material science with the student’s own role, own interests and discipline (major study programme) on the issues related to SDGs

title: Perspectives in Medical Sciences
requirements:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to provide the structural and functional bases as well as the new advances at the molecular and cellular levels for the understanding of how our body works and adapts to changes in the internal and external environment, such as imbalance of chemicals and hormones, extreme alterations in temperature and pressure, as well as after mutation and during aging. In addition, development of knowledge about the causes of disorders in the body and what drugs and new therapeutic approaches can be used for treatment are also areas of focus.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:     Describe the basic human body structures, their functions, and related clinical issues.    Describe how the body regulates itself to encounter both internal and external changes and the consequences if it fails to do so.    Write the relevance and importance of advances in medical sciences to the well-being of mankind.    Read, analyse, and criticise both the general and research articles related to the human body and health issues.    Use different resources such as library and internet to search for body and health related information.    Comment and critique on the controversies and ethical issues that come with the latest advances in medical sciences.
syllabus: The course is roughly divided into two blocks with the first half mainly introducing the perpetuation of life and maintenance of the life processes and the second half emphasizing more on the health issues and physical disorders. All lectures will be conducted by teachers from the School of Biomedical Sciences. Each lecture will start by introducing some basic knowledge of the topics and then move into relating its relevance to the understanding of disease conditions. The impact of some latest advances in medical sciences on mankind will also be discussed. Perpetuation of life and maintenance of life processes Medical sciences help us to better understand the upholding of the healthy, normal status of our body. The seven lectures in this area will illustrate the general anatomical and physiological concepts for understanding the sophisticated yet highly coordinated mechanisms involved in the conception of life and normal functioning of the human body. Topics include:         Topics     Learning Contents       Fertility and infertility    Reproduction is essential for the continued existence of a species. This lecture provides a brief overview on the physiological control of gamete production in men and women, and various factors that determine fertility and contribute towards infertility. Various methods of contraception and how they work will be introduced.      Miracle of life    This lecture gives an account of the human reproductive system and the prenatal development of the human embryo inside mother’s womb. It covers the human embryonic development starting from a fertilized egg which then grows to a cluster of cells and gradually changes and develops into a fetus during pregnancy. It also touches on test-tube baby and techniques for assisted reproduction.      A beautiful mind: wonders of the brain    Our memories, emotions and actions determine who we are. All these are functions of the brain and this lecture will reveal the important features of this mysterious anatomical structure.      Body composition and body fluid    Water makes up of about 60% of our body weight. The various functions of water in humans and the physiological regulation of total body water volume and its contents will be outlined.      Cardiovascular diseases and treatments    Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and ischemic heart diseases are the most prevalent medical conditions in the Western society. This lecture will briefly cover the organization and physiological control of the cardiovascular system. Besides, the common causes of cardiovascular diseases and the basis of current drug treatments will be introduced.      Wireless control in our body: hormones    Hormones are chemical messengers which act as wireless control of life processes in the human body. Travelling from the site of synthesis to distant target tissues or organs via the bloodstream, hormones can exert widespread influences over a long distance. In this lecture, the control and function of various endocrine systems, as well as the causes and symptoms of common endocrine diseases will be discussed.      Life at the extremes    Majority of the human population live in areas close to sea level. The body is highly adapted to the air pressure and oxygen content at this altitude. When a lowlander ascends, the pressure becomes lower and oxygen content reduces, body has to adapt to this new environment. A highlander lives at high altitude for thousands of years and their physical performance is much better than a fully adapted lowlander. The physiological and genetic adaptation process will be described.      Health issues and physical disorders An understanding of the body defense system and disease mechanisms is important for the maintenance of health and the choice of effective treatments. The pathophysiological mechanisms involved in physical disorders induced by deterioration of normal physiological functions or by exposure of the body to foreign substances/organisms will be examined. Topics included:          Topics    Learning Contents      Body defense    Our defense system is a body-wide network consisting of organs, tissues, cells, and small molecules that work together to fight against “foreign” invaders and different kinds of stressors. This lecture aims to introduce the mechanism of body defense and response to infection as one source of body immune reaction. The common hospital-acquired infections and epidemiology will also be discussed.      Targeting our genes    In human, genetic codes are stored in DNA. The human genome contains 3 billion base pairs of nucleotides. Any mutations in the DNA sequence may lead to genetic diseases. The goal of the Human Genome Project is to determine the complete DNA sequence in human. In this lecture, basic knowledge of genetics as well as the causes of genetic diseases will be introduced, and the importance of the human genome project in the study of genetic diseases will be discussed. Enormous progress on genome editing has been made in the past few years. The genome editing tools and prospects of this technology will also be discussed.      Avoiding the top killer - cancer    Cancer is a major killer disease that has long haunted mankind. Carcinogenesis refers to the development of cancerous cells from normal cells. In this lecture, different causes of carcinogenesis and the impact of human activities on the development of cancer will be discussed.      Drugs that we take    This lecture aims to provide students with a basic understanding on what are drugs, how they are discovered, and how they work. General pharmacological principles which are important for understanding the proper use of drugs as medicines will be discussed. Drug abuse and its harmful effects will also be described.      Healthy aging    Aging is a natural process that causes a gradual slowdown of body function and increases the risk of developing diseases. This lecture will explore the effects of aging on different body functions and discuss the strategies that can be used to delay the process of aging and prepare the body and mind for a healthy aging.

title: Perspectives in Clinical Sciences
requirements:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: Health is one of the most important things of our life. Good health allows us to live a full life and free us up to engage in daily activities. However, emerging diseases, such as genetic disorders at birth, highly infectious viral diseases, and aging-related degenerative disorders, can cause significant physical and mental suffering, even premature death.In this course, students are introduced to various types of common diseases that can be encountered in daily life in Hong Kong. The medical knowledge and the physiological mechanisms behind the development of these diseases can provide students a thorough understanding of the functional changes of our body, which will help them make informed decisions about their lifestyle choices and proactively take preventive measures to protect themselves from these diseases.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: • recognize the major causes of common diseases in Hong Kong. • describe the key strategies for disease prevention. • understand the most up-to-date technologies in disease diagnosis and treatment. • integrate and apply the medical knowledge learned from the lectures with real-life scenarios.
syllabus: Course Outline: Four major areas will be covered in this course. Three selected topics of interest will be given under a major area, and each one of them both from a scientific perspective and a clinical perspective.       Areas    Topics    Lecture Contents      Molecular coding of life    Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests       Science:   Genetic codes and genetic diseases.  Clinical:    Clinical considerations and approaches of prenatal diagnosis.      Stem cells and tissue regeneration       Science:   Different types of stem cells and their differentiation potentials.  Clinical:    Potential medical applications of stem cells.      Sense and sensibility    Science:   A look at the human body: the five senses.  Clinical:    Common problems in development.      Growing up    Allergy         Science:   The immune system in our body.  Clinical:    Common types of allergy in Hong Kong and their treatment.      Obesity         Science:   Causes and health risks associated with obesity.  Clinical:    Obesity: What should patients and health providers do?      Gastric problems              Science:   Gastric acid secretion: principles and regulation.  Clinical:    Common upper digestive diseases.      The invaders    Hepatitis B and liver cancer    Science:   Cell cycle, apoptosis and cancer.  Clinical:    The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of hepatitis B infection.      Influenza    Science:   Biology of the influenza virus.  Clinical:    The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of influenza.      HIV and AIDS    Science:   Biology of human immunodeficiency virus.  Clinical:    HIV: from science to medicine.      Growing old    Arthritis       Science:   Purine degradation and gouty arthristis.  Clinical:    Diagnosis and management of arthritis.      Osteoporosis       Science:   Bone metabolism and calcium balance.  Clinical:    Osteoporosis: epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment.      Alzhemier's disease    Science:  The human nervous system.  Clinical:   Pathology of Alzheimer's disease and their treatment.          Course Details and References:   A.     Molecular coding of life   The development from a fertilized egg to a normal functioning human being is a miraculous process. All animals begin life as a fertilized egg. After several round of cell division, the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo, and then a fetus. During development, stem cells can differentiate into different types of cells in our body. Each cell inherits the same set of DNA, but only selected genes are activated. However, any error in the genetic code will result in defects and pathological changes. Currently, prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests are employed to detect these defects. With the diagnosis of such defects, we could devise therapeutic interventions or other treatment regimens to minimize the impacts of these defects. Besides genetic diseases, some common problems might also arise during childhood development, like hearing and speech impairment, visual impairment, delay for motor skills, and mental retardation.   1.      Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests   The genetic code is hidden in DNA. The genetic information stored in the DNA sequence is transferred through mRNA and then finally to proteins. When there are mutations in the DNA sequences, genetic diseases may arise. Prenatal diagnosis is very important in increasing the chance of delivering a healthy baby.    2.      Stem cells and tissue regeneration     The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to Sir John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent stem cells.  This discovery is an important breakthrough in medicinal research. In this lecture, the definition and characteristics of stem cells will be introduced. Methods for stem cell preparation and the potential applications of stem cells for medical therapy will be explained. Current problems and ethical issues on stem cell usage will be discussed.    3.      Sense and sensibility   The molecular and cellular basis of different sensation will be introduced. Common sensory disorders and the effects on childhood development will be explained. Current advances in diagnosis and treatment will be discussed.       B.     Growing up   The immune system in our body helps to protect us against disease by identifying and killing any pathogens from entering the body. However, over-reactivity of this life-saving system will cause allergy that will make troubles for us. Allergic diseases that are commonly found in Hong Kong, like rhinitis and asthma, will be introduced.   Beside allergic diseases, other problems may arise when we grow up from childhood and enter into adulthood. In the past, under-nutrition is a problem in many parts of the world. Nowadays, the problems of over-nutrition and unbalanced diet are becoming more serious in many countries.   Coupled with the lack of exercise, obesity is a common problem among many working adults in Kong Kong. Also, a stressful working environment together with the bacterial infection has made gastric problems commonplace in Hong Kong. If we continue to neglect the warning signals from our bodies, we may finally suffer from lethal organ failure.  1.      Allergy  The immune system protects us against disease by killing the pathogens that enter our body. Disorders of immune system occur when the immune response is hypersensitive, or lacking. Allergy is an immune response excited by allergens. Allergens that are commonly found in Hong Kong include house dust mite, cockroaches, and house moulds.    2.   Obesity   This topic will discuss diet, energy balance, healthy body weight, life styles, genetics and environmental factors in relation to overweight and obesity. It will also emphasize how obesity increases the risk of chronic diseases. The methods to treat obesity will be briefly introduced, including dietary intervention, behavior modification, medications and surgery.   3.     Gastric problems  The Nobel Prize in Physiology & Medicine for 2005 was awarded to Barry J. Marshall and J. Robin Warren for establishment of the linkage between Helicobacter pylori and gastric diseases. The bacteria colonized in the stomach induce many changes in gastric secretion. This topic will address the basic science and clinical manifestation of gastric diseases.      C.     The invaders     The human race is in a state of constant battle with our environment. This struggle for survival includes the fight against microorganisms in the environment. In the past, bacterial infections caused much mortality and morbidity to the human race. With the development of antibiotics, this problem is now under control. However, we are less successful in the development of effective anti-viral drugs. Thus, viral infection has become a serious problem. In this part, three viral infected diseases will be introduced. These include influenza (caused by influenza virus), hepatitis B (caused by hepatitis B virus), and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (caused by human immunodeficiency virus).     1.      Hepatitis B and liver cancer     In Hong Kong, it was estimated that about 10% of the whole population are hepatitis B carriers. The long-term consequences of chronic viral hepatitis infection include liver cancer, chronic liver diseases and cirrhosis. Local studies showed that approximately 80% of patients with liver cancer were hepatitis B carriers. In this module, the relationship between hepatitis B virus and liver diseases will be explored.     2.      Influenza     The annual epidemic and the potential threat of a pandemic render influenza a major infectious disease in the world. Effective control of influenza entails a combination of good sanitary habits and the employment of effective vaccines, diagnostic tests and antiviral drugs.     3.      HIV and AIDS     Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. According to the statistics from the World Health Organization, AIDS accounts for the highest number of deaths in the world. In this module, the structure and organization of HIV, the route of transmission of AIDS, as well as the diagnosis and therapy of AIDS will be discussed.      D.     Growing old   Aging is a natural process of all human beings. Associated with aging, many physiological aspects of the body would start to deteriorate. These include the deterioration of joint functions (which will lead to arthritis), bone functions (which will lead to the development of osteoporosis), and brain functions (which will lead to the development of Alzheimer’s disease). The proper management of these conditions is a concern for the aging population.     1.      Arthritis   Arthritis is a major burden of mobility for the elderly. The development of arthritis is a multifactorial process. This topic will introduce the basic science and the clinical treatment for the disease.   2.      Osteoporosis   Osteoporosis is one of the most common health problems among the elderly, characterized by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissues leading to increased bone fragility and fracture risk. In this topic, the causes, preventive measurements and treatments of osteoporosis will be discussed.   3.      Alzheimer’s disease   The molecular basis of interneuron communication (neurotransmission) will be introduced. Clinical signs and problems of the aged brain will be explained. Advances in understanding and treatment of Alzheimer’s disease will be discussed.

title: Science, Philosophy and Human Life
requirements:

description: A lively, accessible survey of basic issues in critical thinking and philosophy of science as they bear on daily life and our understanding of the world. The course focuses on three general issues: What is science and how is it different from superstition and pseudoscience? How are theories supported by evidence? and Does science give us the truth about reality? Discussions will address topics such as astrology, fortune-telling, and fengshui; parapsychology, extrasensory perception, and ghosts; creationism vs. evolutionary theory; science, religion, and mystical experience; miracle cures, folk medicine, and medical quackery; relativism and truth; scientific progress, scientific revolutions, and rationality; and whether atoms and black holes really exist.
outcome: Describe the nature of science, scientific explanation, and scientific method.    Understand some of the basic issues in philosophy of science.    Explain how science is different from superstition and pseudoscience.    Apply critical thinking skills to scientific issues in daily life.

title: Climate Change and Extreme Weather
requirements:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Science, IDA+X Double Maj. Prog., ASEI+X Double Maj. Prog. or MASE+X Double Maj. Prog.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course covers various issues related to climate and climate change, such as how it is related to our lives, our changing climate in the past, sea level rise, impacts of stratospheric ozone hole and global warming, El Niño events and disastrous climate extremes, tropical cyclones, and our responses to climate change.This course intends to enable students to become knowledgeable in the debate on global environmental change and the relevant adaptation and mitigation strategies, which can provide a clearer understanding of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#13 Climate Action. It can also better prepare them to make informed decisions in their career and personal life in the future complex society where resolving the ever-increasing demand for energy and the preservation of the integrity of the environment and natural resources will be a foremost concern. The technological and policy solutions discussed will also help contribute to address SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy as well as SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being.
outcome: At the end of the course, you should be able to  describe basic features of the earth system  explain the possible reasons for the occurrence of different types of weather and climate phenomena  describe the different types of extreme weather  describe the tools used to (a) identify the past, and (b) predict and project future changes in weather and climate  explain how these tools can be used to estimate the impacts of climate change on the different types of extreme weather  identify the scientific meaning behind different types of climate science data (e.g., rising sea level) and their limitations as non-science students  explore the possible human footprint on the natural variability of climate  understand the discussion behind the adaptation and mitigation strategies towards the global environmental change, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#7 Clean and Affordable Energy, and SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being
syllabus: Part 1 : Introduction This part introduces basic ideas of the meaning of climate, climate change, weather, extreme weather, human interaction with the climate.   Part 2 : The Earth System and Forcings of Weather and Climate This part discusses the basic components of the earth system such as the land surface cover, the ocean and the atmosphere, also features of each component and the interactions between them. Various types of natural and anthropogenic forcings for the climate, including the sun, orbits of the earth, atmospheric and oceanic oscillations, anthropogenic forcings and urbanization are examined.    Part 3 : Extreme Weather This part includes extreme weather such as heavy precipitation, cold surge, heat wave and tropical cyclones, their features including their intensities and occurring frequencies and the extent of their effect on human societies.   Part 4 : Tools to Study and Predict Weather and Climate and their Changes This part explores different tools to study the past and future climate. Tools including analyzed observational data presented on charts such as sea-level change and atmospheric methane concentration change for the recent decades are illustrated. For the period before the recent decades where modern measuring devices were not available, proxy tools such as tree rings, corals and ice cores can be used to estimate the past climate. For the future climate, prediction tools such as computer simulations are covered.   Part 5 : Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies Towards Global Environmental Change This part mentions different options in terms of adaptation and mitigation strategies available and in the future scenarios. Their costs and effectiveness are discussed.

title: Viewing Communication from Speech Therapy
requirements:
Not for students who have taken LING3208 or UGEC3928. 
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix
description: One in every 10 people suffers from at least a kind of communication disorder. It is almost inevitable for people to have encountered individuals with unclear speech, hoarse voice, stuttering, autism spectrum disorder, hearing impairment and dementia etc. in their lifetime. Students without a background in speech and hearing sciences may not have solid understanding of the essentials of human communication and its disorders. This course thus aims to provide tailor-made content suiting all students to cover the fundamentals of these topics from the perspective of speech-language-pathology. The course consists of 3 major components. The first one brings out the essential elements in normal communication. The second component covers what goes wrong in the chain of communication which leads to various communication disorders. The third component introduces various communication disorders in terms of the general characteristics and the practical tips on how to interact with them through case studies. By learning the essential elements of effective communication skills as well as gaining knowledge on how to facilitate interaction with people who have diverse communication and educational needs, this course also helps students to better understand the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) relating to #3 Good Health and Well-being, #4 Inclusive Quality Education and #10 Reduced Inequalities.
outcome: Throughout the course, students will be able to achieve the following objectives through readings, lectures, team discussions, and group work: 1. Identify the various processes involved in successful human communication, including the basic anatomical, neurological, and physiological underpinnings of communication. This will help promote SDG#3 - Good Health and Wellbeing by teaching students relevant strategies to foster positive mental health and well-being. 2. Explain how the breakdown in specific processes can lead to different communication disorders, including behavioral analyses. This will help promote SDG#4 - Quality Education by helping students understand how inclusive education is possible with different approaches. 3. Describe the communication, language, and speech characteristics of individuals with different communication disorders, promoting both SDG#4 - Quality Education and SDG#10 - Reduced Inequalities. 4. Summarize the basic principles of communicating with populations facing various difficulties, promoting empathy and diversity and aligning with SDG#4 and SDG#10. 5. Apply the fundamental knowledge gained in improving one's own communication skills, promoting SDG#3 - Good Health and Wellbeing.

title: Getting to Know Speech and Language Impairment and the Role of Speech Therapist
requirements: Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: A communication disorder is an impairment in the ability to receive, send, process, and comprehend concepts or verbal, nonverbal and graphic symbol systems. A communication disorder may be evident in the processes of hearing, language, and/or speech. A communication disorder may range in severity from mild to profound.Specifically, speech and language impairment (SLI) refers to any one or combination of the following conditions that may lead to communication difficulties – a) speech sound disorders, b) voice disorders, c) fluency disorders, d) language disorders. Students with SLI may encounter difficulties in communicating effectively with others, which may affect one’s self-esteem and development of social relationships. They may have difficulties in understanding and / or giving oral presentations, struggle in following rapid verbal exchanges which may limit their participation in classes. They may also lack confidence in speaking in front of public or a large group of people. They may thus have trouble adapting to the course work and university life. This is partially attributable to the lack of awareness of SLI among university students and teachers. The course aims to provide general education on knowledge and skills relating to daily communications with students with Speech and Language Impairment (SLI) in academic or social settings, and facilitate equal access to quality education. This course is an SDG-GE course, which aims to promote good health and well-being in the university population, reduce inequality among students with different abilities, and thus facilitate equal access to quality education. The course also helps students to understand the social and economic considerations relevant to speech and language impairment (SLI).

title: Exploring the Enigmatic Oceans
requirements:
Not for majors in School of Life Sciences; not for students in the following concentration areas of NSCI: Biological Sciences; Biotechnology; Environmental Studies; and Food and Nutrition.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course aims to provide an overview of the oceans and the roles of natural and anthropogenic impacts on shaping the physical and biological aspects of the oceans. The main themes of the course include the ocean processes, the marine ecosystems and their inhabitants, and the relationships between oceans and mankind. Emphasis will be placed on how natural processes shape the oceans, how the inhabitants survive the marine environment, how we depend on the oceans, the impact of anthropogenic processes on the oceans, and how the future of mankind is affected by the oceans. Examples of topics covered include: the Earth and the oceans, ecosystems of the oceans, marine organisms and their adaptations to the marine environment, exploitation of the oceans, and the management and conservation of the oceans. Altogether, this course also aims to raise awareness and promote the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to SDG#13 Climate Action and SDG#14 Life Below Water. A laboratory visit to the Simon F.S. Li Marine Science Laboratory will be included to demonstrate the methodology and instruments used in marine research.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:   1.   Recognise the nature and importance of the oceans, and aware that human beings are part of the nature, 2.   Recognise the nature of various marine ecosystems, and compare the characteristics and ecological importance of the individual marine ecosystems; 3.   Identify the factors influencing the various ocean processes, and recognise their interactions and their impact on human life; 4.   Appraise how the balance of the natural environment is maintained and how the oceans as the biggest biome of Earth recycles its living and non-living components through the natural recycling processes; 5.   Recognise the characteristics of various marine organisms, relate their structural or physiological adaptations to the specific marine environments where they survive, and compare ways through which organisms in different marine ecosystems adapt to survive; 6.   Acquire hands-on experience on the theory and application of the common instruments used in marine research through a visit to the Simon F.S. Li Marine Science Laboratory; 7.   Recognise the importance of the oceans as a source of fossil and renewable energy, minerals, food and space for human survival and development; 8.     Explain the effects of climate change, marine pollution and over-exploitation of marine resources, and to recognise and affirm the role of humanity in conserving nature in particular the vulnerable marine environment; 9.     Able to collect, analyse, and compile information and data on topics related to the oceans; and construct and submit a project report on the integrated information, as well as delivering the report to the whole class in form of an oral presentation. 10.  Recognize the urgency of SDG# 13 Climate Action in taking action to combat climate change and its impacts
syllabus: Theme 1: The Earth, the Oceans & Ocean Processes Contents: (i) overview of the Earth and the major oceans, zonation of the ocean and the respective physical and chemical parameters; (ii) the ocean processes and how their interactions shape global conditions such as climates & weather, and (iii) natural cycling of various elements.   Theme 2: Marine Ecosystems Contents: (i) overview of the characteristics of the marine environment; (ii) coastal ecosystems such as mangroves and coral reefs etc, (iii) pelagic ecosystems such as the open ocean and the deep ocean, and (iv) the hydrothermal vent and cold seep ecosystems.   Theme 3: Marine Organisms A variety of marine organisms will be discussed, in particular (i) the plankton and their importance; (ii) organisms which show specific adaptation to the marine environment; and (iii) whales and dolphins. Emphasis will be placed on the interactions of the organisms with the environment and their survival, and the impact of mankind on the organisms.   Theme 4: Ocean and Man Contents: (i) exploitation and conservation of the resources from the oceans; (ii) fisheries/whaling and aquaculture as means of obtaining food from the sea; (iii) organisms threatened by anthropogenic impact and the concepts of endangered organisms; and (iv) marine pollution, remediation and climate actions.

title: Forces of Life
requirements:
Not for Physics Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: All lifeforms are governed by the law of physics. This course surveys how our living world cleverly and sometimes surprisingly deploys the principles of physics: we will first have a macroscopic view of how energy is transported in ecosystem without violating the laws of thermodynamics. This is followed by discussion on how physical concepts are embedded in everyday activities of living organisms such as movement, communication, hunting and navigation. As a closing remark, we will go beyond our own planet and discuss how the physical environment in other habitable exoplanets may shape potential lifeform. Through exploring the delicate interplay between lifeforms and the physical world, this course aims at looking at our living world from a new perspective and cultivating a sense of awe for nature. No prior knowledge in physics or biology is expected.
